content.text:
Please analyze this codebase and create a CLAUDE.md file, which will be given to future instances of Claude Code to operate in this repository.
            
What to add:
1. Commands that will be commonly used, such as how to build, lint, and run tests. Include the necessary commands to develop in this codebase, such as how to run a single test.
2. High-level code architecture and structure so that future instances can be productive more quickly. Focus on the "big picture" architecture that requires reading multiple files to understand

Usage notes:
- If there's already a CLAUDE.md, suggest improvements to it.
- When you make the initial CLAUDE.md, do not repeat yourself and do not include obvious instructions like "Provide helpful error messages to users", "Write unit tests for all new utilities", "Never include sensitive information (API keys, tokens) in code or commits" 
- Avoid listing every component or file structure that can be easily discovered
- Don't include generic development practices
- If there are Cursor rules (in .cursor/rules/ or .cursorrules) or Copilot rules (in .github/copilot-instructions.md), make sure to include the important parts.
- If there is a README.md, make sure to include the important parts. 
- Do not make up information such as "Common Development Tasks", "Tips for Development", "Support and Documentation" unless this is expressly included in other files that you read.
- Be sure to prefix the file with the following text:

```
# CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.
```
I'll analyze the codebase to understand its architecture and create a comprehensive CLAUDE.md file. Let me start by examining the structure and key files.

Examine project structure and key directories
Review existing configuration files (vite, tsconfig, etc.)
Analyze source code architecture and patterns
Create comprehensive CLAUDE.md file

1â†’## Hansken UI (HUI) 2â†’ 3â†’### Overview 4â†’ 5â†’- Getting started 6â†’- Stack & Setup 7â†’- Folder structure 8â†’- Scripts 9â†’- .env 10â†’- Feature Flags 11â†’- Git hooks 12â†’- Multilingual 13â†’- Redux 14â†’- Contributing 15â†’- Add-ons 16â†’- Cypress 17â†’- Under construction page 18â†’ 19â†’### Getting started 20â†’ 21â†’- [With NPM](./docs/NPM.md) 22â†’- [With Docker](./docs/Docker.md) 23â†’ 24â†’```bash 25â†’npm start 26â†’``` 27â†’ 28â†’### Stack & Setup 29â†’ 30â†’- TypeScript 4.5+ 31â†’- React v17.0.1+ (supports: hooks, lazy, suspense) 32â†’- React-router 33â†’- Redux & Redux-Thunk 34â†’- Jest 35â†’- MaterialUI 36â†’- CSS & Styling 37â†’- Cypress for e2e testing 38â†’ 39â†’### Folder structure 40â†’ 41â†’#### /addons 42â†’ 43â†’This folder contains all the addons for HUI, the rest of the code is independent from this code. For more information: [Add-ons](#Add-ons) 44â†’ 45â†’#### /components 46â†’ 47â†’In this folder are all **presentational components**. For more information about these components: [Guidelines](./docs/Guidelines.md) 48â†’ 49â†’#### /constants 50â†’ 51â†’All constants for this application are found in this map. These are Routes, Endpoints en Date formatting configuration. 52â†’ 53â†’#### /pages 54â†’ 55â†’In this folder are all page **pages**. These are the pages that are called by [./src/App.tsx](./src/App.tsx). A decent amount of the pages are exactly the same, which is why the template is only defined once in [./src/pages/generic-pages/GenericLayoutPage.tsx](./src/pages/generic-pages/GenericLayoutPage.tsx). This component gets a bunch of data, which are defined in the same directory. The pages are categorized by their highest parent in the folder structure. 56â†’ 57â†’How to add a page is explained in the [Guidelines](./docs/Guidelines.md) 58â†’ 59â†’#### /lib 60â†’ 61â†’In the lib folder are reusable logic functions such as helpers for arrays, objecten en strings. It only contains helper functions that are reused on multiple places, not helper functions for a component itself. 62â†’ 63â†’#### /locales 64â†’ 65â†’This contains all the translations in JSON format. The strucutre (keys) are the same for every language. The values are the translation for the language. How to use translations is explained in [Multilingual](#Multilingual) 66â†’ 67â†’#### /redux 68â†’ 69â†’All Redux related code is in this folder. For every state property there is a folder with their Actions and Reducer. 70â†’In [src/redux/storage.ts](./src/redux/storage.ts) is defined which state properties are saved as SessionStorage, this is to remember state on refreshing a page. 71â†’ 72â†’For more information [Redux Docs](/docs/Redux%20State%20Store.md) 73â†’ 74â†’#### /rest 75â†’ 76â†’In this folder are all the functions located for fetching of data, and TypeScript interfaces for the response from the backend. 77â†’ 78â†’### Scripts 79â†’ 80â†’| Script | Description | 81â†’| -------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | --- | 82â†’| `npm start` | Run local dev server and refreshes browser when there are changes in `./src/*` | 83â†’| `npm build` | Create build of the project | 84â†’| `npm serve` | Starts a local web server that serves the built | 85â†’| `npm run lint` | Run TSLint | 86â†’| `npm run tsc` | Run TypeScript compiler | 87â†’| `npm run prettier` | Run Prettier to format the code | 88â†’| `npm test` | Run Vitest to run all the tests (watch mode) (specifiy file to run test in isolation) | 89â†’| `npm run test:ci` | Run Vitest without watch mode but include coverage report | 90â†’| `npm run test:ci -- -u` | Run test:ci and update the page snapshots | 91â†’| `npm run createReleaseNote` | Adds a release note in one file to the releaseNotes directory. | 92â†’| `npm run mergeReleaseNotes` | Merges all release note files into `releaseNotes/releaseNotes.mjs` | 93â†’| `npm run removeReleaseNoteFiles` | Removes all single note files | | 94â†’| `npm run prepush` | This script runs before `git push`, it runs the compiler, linter and tests | 95â†’ 96â†’### .env 97â†’ 98â†’In the [.env](./.env) file are all environment variables that are needed to run the application. These variables are automatically available within React when you run `npm start` of `npm build`. **Important:** all variables need to be prefixed with `REACT_APP_`. otherwise React ignores them. So: 99â†’ 100â†’``` 101â†’MY_VARIABLE=123 // Doesnt work! 102â†’REACT_APP_MY_VARIABLE=123 // works :-) 103â†’``` 104â†’ 105â†’To read the variables in React: 106â†’ 107â†’```ts 108â†’export const MY_VARIABLE = process.env.REACT_APP_MY_VARIABLE 109â†’``` 110â†’ 111â†’### Feature Flags 112â†’ 113â†’Feature flags allow to toggle parts of the code based on a flag that can be set per Environment. 114â†’ 115â†’#### Define a Feature Flag 116â†’ 117â†’To define a Feature Flag you need to add it to the constants file `src/constants/features.ts` 118â†’For now we only accept `switch` flags which have a boolean, but in the future we can add more types like `Hansken Version` or string 119â†’The definition also contains the default value if no config is present in an environment 120â†’ 121â†’Format: 122â†’ 123â†’``` 124â†’{ 125â†’ "feature_flag_name": { 126â†’ type: "switch", 127â†’ defaultValue: false 128â†’ }, 129â†’ ... 130â†’} 131â†’``` 132â†’ 133â†’#### Set the Feature Flag value per environment 134â†’ 135â†’To set the value per environment you update the `/public/config.json` 136â†’ 137â†’Format: 138â†’ 139â†’``` 140â†’{ 141â†’ ... 142â†’ "features": { 143â†’ "feature_flag_name": true 144â†’ }, 145â†’ ... 146â†’} 147â†’``` 148â†’ 149â†’#### Use the Feature flag to toggle specific code 150â†’ 151â†’There is a component that will show how feature flags work: `src/pages/Dashboard/components/FeatureFlags/FeatureFlags.tsx` 152â†’Features are stored in Redux on load of the application, you can retrieve all features like this: 153â†’ 154â†’``` 155â†’const features = useAppSelector(state => state.features) 156â†’``` 157â†’ 158â†’To get a specific Feature Flag value you can use this: 159â†’ 160â†’``` 161â†’const showFeatureFlagsActive = useFeatureSelector("feature_flag_name") 162â†’``` 163â†’ 164â†’#### Override a Feature Flag value per URL Parameter 165â†’ 166â†’There are situations where you want to show a feature without having to update a environment config (maybe to send a link to a tester) 167â†’ 168â†’You can add this to the query parameters in the url to set a value: 169â†’`switch.feature_flag_name=1` or `switch.feature_flag_name=0` to enable or disable the feature flag 170â†’ 171â†’### Git hooks 172â†’ 173â†’Husky is installed to add Git hooks. There are two hooks configured: 174â†’ 175â†’- `precommit`: Runs prettier before every commit. 176â†’- `prepush`: For every push it runs `npm run prepush`. This runs the compiler, linter and tests, to make sure it the code doesnt have any issues. In the future we will move this to a CI. 177â†’ 178â†’### Release Notes 179â†’ 180â†’Release notes make sure each user of the application is up to date with new features, bugfixes, and misc activities done by the developers. Adding release notes should work like this: 181â†’ 182â†’- Whenever you are finished with a ticket, generate a release note using `npm run createReleaseNote` 183â†’- You will get some prompts asking what note you would like to add for technical and non-technical users 184â†’ 185â†’The developer who prepares new releases needs to merge these notes so that the final files are up to date: 186â†’ 187â†’- run `npm run mergeReleaseNotes` to make the `releaseNotes/releaseNotes.mjs` and the `ReleaseNotes.md` file up to date 188â†’- When you are finished, you can run `npm run removeReleaseNoteFiles` to remove all single files. 189â†’ 190â†’#### For new developers: Git does not track mere directories, so a new developer should add the following directories with this structure to its root after cloning the repository: 191â†’ 192â†’``` 193â†’huib-ui 194â†’â””â”€â”€â”€releaseNotes 195â†’â”‚ â”‚ releaseNotes.mjs 196â†’â”‚ â””â”€â”€â”€technical 197â†’â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ bugfix 198â†’â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ features 199â†’â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ misc 200â†’â”‚ â””â”€â”€â”€ui 201â†’â”‚ â”‚ | bugfix 202â†’â”‚ â”‚ | features 203â†’â”‚ â”‚ | misc 204â†’``` 205â†’ 206â†’### Multilingual 207â†’ 208â†’HUI supports multiple languages based on the library `i18next` en `react-i18next`. The translations can be found in folders (per language) under [./src/locales/](./src/locales/). The files are seperated for several categories. Per language, every file has the same structure with its own translations: `/en/general.json`, `/nl/general.json`, `/nl/conversations.json` etc etc. 209â†’ 210â†’Usage of translation: 211â†’ 212â†’```tsx 213â†’import { useTranslation } from 'react-i18next' 214â†’const { t } = useTranslation('translation') 215â†’return 216â†’``` 217â†’ 218â†’### Using Redux 219â†’ 220â†’Redux is integrated for storage of information 221â†’More information about redux can be found in [/docs/Redux State Store.md/](/docs/Redux%20State%20Store.md) 222â†’ 223â†’#### Getting data from Redux 224â†’ 225â†’```tsx 226â†’const { uid: selectedTraceUid } = useAppSelector((state: AppState) => state.traceDetailSettings.trace) 227â†’``` 228â†’ 229â†’#### Dispatching data to redux 230â†’ 231â†’```tsx 232â†’const dispatch = useAppDispatch() 233â†’dispatch(setSelectedTrace('')) 234â†’``` 235â†’ 236â†’### Contributing 237â†’ 238â†’Pull requests are welcome. Before major changes please open an issue first to discuss what you would like to change. 239â†’Please read the [Guidelines](./docs/Guidelines.md) and update the tests when required. 240â†’ 241â†’### Expert mode 242â†’ 243â†’Enable the expert mode in User Settings. 244â†’ 245â†’To make navigation items only to be seen when the expert mode is enabled, fill the array in `src/components/Sidemenu/data/expertMenuItem.ts` 246â†’ 247â†’### Metrics (Matomo) 248â†’ 249â†’Matomo is an alternative for Google Analytics which protects your data and customer privacy. It is not included in Hansken, your organisation has to run it On-Premise. 250â†’It is completely free, and you controle the data. 251â†’We still have to verify if Matomo currently works correctly with the default USER ids and cross domain tracking. It might not be 100% correct. 252â†’If you encounter incorrect logging of Matomo please contact the Huib developers. 253â†’ 254â†’Currently the following things are tracked: 255â†’- Page url's visited 256â†’- Tracks which tabs are visited in traceDetails 257â†’- Click events on 'trace paths', 'open parent/chatConversation' 258â†’- Usage of global/local filters (opening /applying of filters no details) 259â†’- Search page => adding more filters, opening guideline/ hql-cheat-sheet 260â†’- Opening search history 261â†’ 262â†’How to configure Matomo: 263â†’In Huib: 264â†’``` 265â†’ REACT_APP_MATOMO_DOMAIN: 'dev', 266â†’ REACT_APP_MATOMO_API:'http://localhost:8080', 267â†’ REACT_APP_MATOMO_SITE_ID:1, 268â†’``` 269â†’In Matomo: 270â†’You can configure multiple websites to track, make sure the name and id are the same as the huib settings and it will receive the data. 271â†’``` 272â†’name: 'dev' // Should be the same as REACT_APP_MATOMO_DOMAIN 273â†’urls: http://localhost:3000 // Should be the URL it should hit on. Check documentation of Matomo when you work with sub-domains and want to split develop from production 274â†’id: 1 // Should be the same as the SITE_ID 275â†’``` 276â†’ 277â†’ 278â†’ 279â†’### Add-ons 280â†’ 281â†’HUI supports add-ons. In the folder [src/addons](./src/addons) there needs to be a folder for every addon that needs to be installed. The code needs to be independent. 282â†’ 283â†’In the index file an export to the addon needs to be added: [src/addons/index.ts](./src/addons/index.ts) 284â†’ 285â†’In the Admin Panel in HUI are automatically the add-ons presented that are exported from `src/addons/index.ts` as `AdminAddons`. 286â†’ 287â†’#### Adding (sub)pages as add-ons 288â†’ 289â†’Create a folder called `AddonMenu` in `src/addons/` with the file `index.ts`. Here you can define new menu items. The properties that are important here, are `index`, `path`, and `replace`. All original menu items have an `index`, starting at `001a`. Use the letters to define the position of your new menu item. So, if you want your new menu item to appear directly after the first item, you can give your new menu item the index `001b`. If you want to replace an original item (and give it a new position, for example), you can use `replace: true`. If you want to create a subpage, use `path` to define its position using the parent ids, starting at the top level parent. For example, when adding something to System > Windows > Registry, use `path: ['system', 'windows', 'registry']`. You don't need `index` in this case. Also, make sure you add `AddonMenu` to `FunctionAddons` in `src/addons/index.ts`. 290â†’ 291â†’```tsx 292â†’import { faLightbulb } from '@fortawesome/free-solid-svg-icons' 293â†’import { IAddonMenuItem } from 'src/components/Sidemenu/data/menuItems' 294â†’import { ProjectId } from 'src/rest/case/Case' 295â†’ 296â†’export const ADDON_PAGES = { 297â†’ ADDON_PAGE: '/case/:caseId/addon-page', 298â†’} 299â†’ 300â†’// This createPageUrl knows all the addon page urls 301â†’export const createPageUrl = (caseId: ProjectId, page: keyof typeof ADDON_PAGES): string => 302â†’ ADDON_PAGES[page].replace(':caseId', caseId) 303â†’ 304â†’const addonPage = (caseId: ProjectId): IAddonMenuItem[] | [] => [ 305â†’ { 306â†’ id: 'addon-page', 307â†’ label: 'My new addon page', 308â†’ index: '013b', 309â†’ icon: faLightbulb, 310â†’ subs: [], 311â†’ link: createPageUrl(caseId, 'ADDON_PAGE'), 312â†’ }, 313â†’] 314â†’ 315â†’export const AddonMenu = (caseId: ProjectId): IAddonMenuItem[] => [...addonPage(caseId)] 316â†’``` 317â†’ 318â†’Next, you need can add the routers directly in the `src/addons/index.ts` file, or a separate file / folder. 319â†’It is recommended to put it in a separate file, if you have multiple addon pages. 320â†’ 321â†’Directly in src/addons/index.ts: 322â†’Change the index.ts to index.tsx otherwise you can't import `AddonComponent` 323â†’ 324â†’```tsx 325â†’import { AddonRoutes } from './AddonRouter' 326â†’ 327â†’export const AddonRouters: AddonRouteProps[] = [ 328â†’ { 329â†’ path: ADDON_PAGES.ADDON_PAGE, 330â†’ element: , 331â†’ }, 332â†’] 333â†’``` 334â†’ 335â†’OR 336â†’ 337â†’Add the reference towards the file in src/addons/index.ts: 338â†’ 339â†’```tsx 340â†’import { AddonRoutes } from './AddonRouter' 341â†’ 342â†’export const AddonRouters: AddonRouteProps[] = AddonRoutes 343â†’``` 344â†’ 345â†’In new file 'AddonRouter.tsx' 346â†’ 347â†’```tsx 348â†’import AddonComponent from 'src/components/AddonComponent/AddonComponent' 349â†’import { AddonRouteProps } from '..' 350â†’import { ADDON_PAGES } from '../AddonMenu' 351â†’ 352â†’export const AddonRoutes: AddonRouteProps[] = [ 353â†’ { 354â†’ path: ADDON_PAGES.ADDON, 355â†’ element: , 356â†’ }, 357â†’ { 358â†’ path: ADDON_PAGES.ADDON_B, 359â†’ element: , 360â†’ }, 361â†’ { 362â†’ path: ADDON_PAGES.ADDON_C, 363â†’ element: , 364â†’ }, 365â†’] 366â†’``` 367â†’ 368â†’Creating the page component itself works the same as creating any other `UIAddon` or `AdminAddon`. 369â†’ 370â†’#### Adding a new add-on 371â†’ 372â†’Create a folder `my-addon` in `src/addons/` with the file: `index.ts`. 373â†’ 374â†’`src/addons/my-addon/index.ts`: 375â†’ 376â†’```tsx 377â†’import React from 'react' 378â†’export const MyAddon = () =>
My add-on component
379â†’``` 380â†’ 381â†’`src/addons/index.ts`: 382â†’Export all add-ons that need to be visible, there is a separation between `UIAddons`: visible for user, and `AdminAddons`: visible in admin-panel, and `FunctionAddons`: addons that are invisible on the background, For example a tracker of logger. 383â†’ 384â†’```ts 385â†’import { MyAddon } from './my-addon' 386â†’import { MyAdminAddon } from './my-admin-addon' 387â†’import { MyOtherAdminAddon } from './my-other-admin-addon' 388â†’import { MyFunctionAddon } from './my-fn-addon' 389â†’import { AddonMenu, ADDON_PAGES } from './addonMenu' 390â†’import addonPageExample from './testing' 391â†’ 392â†’export type UIAddon = typeof addonPageExample 393â†’export const UIAddons = { addonPageExample } 394â†’ 395â†’export type AdminAddon = typeof MyAdminAddon | typeof MyOtherAdminAddon 396â†’export const AdminAddons = { 397â†’ MyAdminAddon, 398â†’ MyOtherAdminAddon, 399â†’} 400â†’ 401â†’export type AddonComponentTypeKey = keyof typeof UIAddons | keyof typeof AdminAddons 402â†’export type AddonComponentType = UIAddon | AdminAddon 403â†’ 404â†’export type FunctionAddonTypeKey = any 405â†’export type FunctionAddonType = typeof AddonMenu 406â†’export const FunctionAddons = { AddonMenu } 407â†’``` 408â†’ 409â†’When there are no add-ons installed `src/addons/index.ts` looks like: 410â†’ 411â†’```tsx 412â†’export type UIAddon = any 413â†’export const UIAddons = {} 414â†’ 415â†’export type AdminAddon = any 416â†’export const AdminAddons = {} 417â†’ 418â†’export type AddonComponentTypeKey = keyof typeof UIAddons | keyof typeof AdminAddons 419â†’export type AddonComponentType = UIAddon | AdminAddon 420â†’ 421â†’export type FunctionAddonTypeKey = any 422â†’export type FunctionAddonType = any 423â†’export const FunctionAddons = {} 424â†’``` 425â†’ 426â†’Note: this structure is also located in `index.default.ts`in the addons folder. 427â†’ 428â†’When `removeInternals.sh` is executed it removed all addons and renames `index.default.ts` to `index.ts` to remove all installed addons. 429â†’ 430â†’### Setup Cypress 431â†’ 432â†’Cypress is used for automated UI testing. Currently the tests can only be ran against HUIB as part of a Hansken environment running on the same domain. To be able to run the Cypress tests a file `./cypress/secrets.json` containing the Hansken username and password needs to be created, with the following contents: 433â†’ 434â†’``` 435â†’{ 436â†’ "env": "local", 437â†’ "training": { 438â†’ "username": "[username_here]", 439â†’ "password": "[password_here]" 440â†’ }, 441â†’ "local": { 442â†’ "username": "[username_here]", 443â†’ "password": "[password_here]" 444â†’ } 445â†’} 446â†’``` 447â†’ 448â†’Use the `env` field to select which username/password is used. 449â†’ 450â†’In `./cypress/cypress.config.ts` the `baseUrl` can be defined to run against a Hansken environment of choice. 451â†’ 452â†’Run the tests with `task cypress`, [Task](https://taskfile.dev/) is required. 453â†’ 454â†’### Under construction page 455â†’ 456â†’To show the under construction page, that doesn't do any network calls: 457â†’ 458â†’Run: 459â†’ 460â†’- `./scripts/setHuiUnderconstruction.sh` 461â†’- `npm i` 462â†’ Then deploy the UI to production as normal 463â†’ 464â†’### Using Styled Components with props 465â†’ 466â†’When you pass props to a Styled Component, that prop will eventually be passed as an attribute to the DOM element. This will result in React warnings. To prevent these warnings from happening, you must pass `shouldForwardProp` to the Styled Component. It's syntax is as follows: 467â†’ 468â†’`{ shouldForwardProp: (prop: string) => !['fullHeight'].includes(prop), }` 469â†’ 470â†’Provide this as a second argument of the Styled Component declaration. You should not import `shouldForwardProp` from a external source. It rather works as an implicit method of `styled`. 471â†’ 472â†’### UI Themes 473â†’ 474â†’From build 391, different themes have been enabled for the user to choose. These are: light, dark, hacker, and hot. It is important to test new UI components in each theme, so ensure a good user experience. 475â†’ 476â†’Provide the theme to a Styled Component, use the following format: 477â†’ 478â†’``` 479â†’export const SearchButton = styled(Button)(({ theme }) => ` 480â†’ background-color: ${theme.palette.primary.main}; 481â†’ color: ${theme.palette.getContrastText(theme.palette.primary.main)}; 482â†’ min-width: 40px; 483â†’`) 484â†’``` 485â†’ 486â†’As can be seen in this example, you can provide a contrasting color to the text if needed. 487â†’ 488â†’If, in specific cases, you need a lighter or darker color, this can be achieved using the `lighten` or `darken` method. Provide the color as the first argument, and the opacity ratio as the second argument. 489â†’ 490â†’``` 491â†’${lighten(theme.palette.primary.main, 0.5)} 492â†’``` 493â†’ Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it looks malicious. ## Hansken UI (HUI) ### Overview - Getting started - Stack & Setup - Folder structure - Scripts - .env - Feature Flags - Git hooks - Multilingual - Redux - Contributing - Add-ons - Cypress - Under construction page ### Getting started - [With NPM](./docs/NPM.md) - [With Docker](./docs/Docker.md) ```bash npm start ``` ### Stack & Setup - TypeScript 4.5+ - React v17.0.1+ (supports: hooks, lazy, suspense) - React-router - Redux & Redux-Thunk - Jest - MaterialUI - CSS & Styling - Cypress for e2e testing ### Folder structure #### /addons This folder contains all the addons for HUI, the rest of the code is independent from this code. For more information: [Add-ons](#Add-ons) #### /components In this folder are all **presentational components**. For more information about these components: [Guidelines](./docs/Guidelines.md) #### /constants All constants for this application are found in this map. These are Routes, Endpoints en Date formatting configuration. #### /pages In this folder are all page **pages**. These are the pages that are called by [./src/App.tsx](./src/App.tsx). A decent amount of the pages are exactly the same, which is why the template is only defined once in [./src/pages/generic-pages/GenericLayoutPage.tsx](./src/pages/generic-pages/GenericLayoutPage.tsx). This component gets a bunch of data, which are defined in the same directory. The pages are categorized by their highest parent in the folder structure. How to add a page is explained in the [Guidelines](./docs/Guidelines.md) #### /lib In the lib folder are reusable logic functions such as helpers for arrays, objecten en strings. It only contains helper functions that are reused on multiple places, not helper functions for a component itself. #### /locales This contains all the translations in JSON format. The strucutre (keys) are the same for every language. The values are the translation for the language. How to use translations is explained in [Multilingual](#Multilingual) #### /redux All Redux related code is in this folder. For every state property there is a folder with their Actions and Reducer. In [src/redux/storage.ts](./src/redux/storage.ts) is defined which state properties are saved as SessionStorage, this is to remember state on refreshing a page. For more information [Redux Docs](/docs/Redux%20State%20Store.md) #### /rest In this folder are all the functions located for fetching of data, and TypeScript interfaces for the response from the backend. ### Scripts | Script | Description | | -------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | --- | | `npm start` | Run local dev server and refreshes browser when there are changes in `./src/*` | | `npm build` | Create build of the project | | `npm serve` | Starts a local web server that serves the built | | `npm run lint` | Run TSLint | | `npm run tsc` | Run TypeScript compiler | | `npm run prettier` | Run Prettier to format the code | | `npm test` | Run Vitest to run all the tests (watch mode) (specifiy file to run test in isolation) | | `npm run test:ci` | Run Vitest without watch mode but include coverage report | | `npm run test:ci -- -u` | Run test:ci and update the page snapshots | | `npm run createReleaseNote` | Adds a release note in one file to the releaseNotes directory. | | `npm run mergeReleaseNotes` | Merges all release note files into `releaseNotes/releaseNotes.mjs` | | `npm run removeReleaseNoteFiles` | Removes all single note files | | | `npm run prepush` | This script runs before `git push`, it runs the compiler, linter and tests | ### .env In the [.env](./.env) file are all environment variables that are needed to run the application. These variables are automatically available within React when you run `npm start` of `npm build`. **Important:** all variables need to be prefixed with `REACT_APP_`. otherwise React ignores them. So: ``` MY_VARIABLE=123 // Doesnt work! REACT_APP_MY_VARIABLE=123 // works :-) ``` To read the variables in React: ```ts export const MY_VARIABLE = process.env.REACT_APP_MY_VARIABLE ``` ### Feature Flags Feature flags allow to toggle parts of the code based on a flag that can be set per Environment. #### Define a Feature Flag To define a Feature Flag you need to add it to the constants file `src/constants/features.ts` For now we only accept `switch` flags which have a boolean, but in the future we can add more types like `Hansken Version` or string The definition also contains the default value if no config is present in an environment Format: ``` { "feature_flag_name": { type: "switch", defaultValue: false }, ... } ``` #### Set the Feature Flag value per environment To set the value per environment you update the `/public/config.json` Format: ``` { ... "features": { "feature_flag_name": true }, ... } ``` #### Use the Feature flag to toggle specific code There is a component that will show how feature flags work: `src/pages/Dashboard/components/FeatureFlags/FeatureFlags.tsx` Features are stored in Redux on load of the application, you can retrieve all features like this: ``` const features = useAppSelector(state => state.features) ``` To get a specific Feature Flag value you can use this: ``` const showFeatureFlagsActive = useFeatureSelector("feature_flag_name") ``` #### Override a Feature Flag value per URL Parameter There are situations where you want to show a feature without having to update a environment config (maybe to send a link to a tester) You can add this to the query parameters in the url to set a value: `switch.feature_flag_name=1` or `switch.feature_flag_name=0` to enable or disable the feature flag ### Git hooks Husky is installed to add Git hooks. There are two hooks configured: - `precommit`: Runs prettier before every commit. - `prepush`: For every push it runs `npm run prepush`. This runs the compiler, linter and tests, to make sure it the code doesnt have any issues. In the future we will move this to a CI. ### Release Notes Release notes make sure each user of the application is up to date with new features, bugfixes, and misc activities done by the developers. Adding release notes should work like this: - Whenever you are finished with a ticket, generate a release note using `npm run createReleaseNote` - You will get some prompts asking what note you would like to add for technical and non-technical users The developer who prepares new releases needs to merge these notes so that the final files are up to date: - run `npm run mergeReleaseNotes` to make the `releaseNotes/releaseNotes.mjs` and the `ReleaseNotes.md` file up to date - When you are finished, you can run `npm run removeReleaseNoteFiles` to remove all single files. #### For new developers: Git does not track mere directories, so a new developer should add the following directories with this structure to its root after cloning the repository: ``` huib-ui â””â”€â”€â”€releaseNotes â”‚ â”‚ releaseNotes.mjs â”‚ â””â”€â”€â”€technical â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ bugfix â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ features â”‚ â”‚ â”‚ misc â”‚ â””â”€â”€â”€ui â”‚ â”‚ | bugfix â”‚ â”‚ | features â”‚ â”‚ | misc ``` ### Multilingual HUI supports multiple languages based on the library `i18next` en `react-i18next`. The translations can be found in folders (per language) under [./src/locales/](./src/locales/). The files are seperated for several categories. Per language, every file has the same structure with its own translations: `/en/general.json`, `/nl/general.json`, `/nl/conversations.json` etc etc. Usage of translation: ```tsx import { useTranslation } from 'react-i18next' const { t } = useTranslation('translation') return ``` ### Using Redux Redux is integrated for storage of information More information about redux can be found in [/docs/Redux State Store.md/](/docs/Redux%20State%20Store.md) #### Getting data from Redux ```tsx const { uid: selectedTraceUid } = useAppSelector((state: AppState) => state.traceDetailSettings.trace) ``` #### Dispatching data to redux ```tsx const dispatch = useAppDispatch() dispatch(setSelectedTrace('')) ``` ### Contributing Pull requests are welcome. Before major changes please open an issue first to discuss what you would like to change. Please read the [Guidelines](./docs/Guidelines.md) and update the tests when required. ### Expert mode Enable the expert mode in User Settings. To make navigation items only to be seen when the expert mode is enabled, fill the array in `src/components/Sidemenu/data/expertMenuItem.ts` ### Metrics (Matomo) Matomo is an alternative for Google Analytics which protects your data and customer privacy. It is not included in Hansken, your organisation has to run it On-Premise. It is completely free, and you controle the data. We still have to verify if Matomo currently works correctly with the default USER ids and cross domain tracking. It might not be 100% correct. If you encounter incorrect logging of Matomo please contact the Huib developers. Currently the following things are tracked: - Page url's visited - Tracks which tabs are visited in traceDetails - Click events on 'trace paths', 'open parent/chatConversation' - Usage of global/local filters (opening /applying of filters no details) - Search page => adding more filters, opening guideline/ hql-cheat-sheet - Opening search history How to configure Matomo: In Huib: ``` REACT_APP_MATOMO_DOMAIN: 'dev', REACT_APP_MATOMO_API:'http://localhost:8080', REACT_APP_MATOMO_SITE_ID:1, ``` In Matomo: You can configure multiple websites to track, make sure the name and id are the same as the huib settings and it will receive the data. ``` name: 'dev' // Should be the same as REACT_APP_MATOMO_DOMAIN urls: http://localhost:3000 // Should be the URL it should hit on. Check documentation of Matomo when you work with sub-domains and want to split develop from production id: 1 // Should be the same as the SITE_ID ``` ### Add-ons HUI supports add-ons. In the folder [src/addons](./src/addons) there needs to be a folder for every addon that needs to be installed. The code needs to be independent. In the index file an export to the addon needs to be added: [src/addons/index.ts](./src/addons/index.ts) In the Admin Panel in HUI are automatically the add-ons presented that are exported from `src/addons/index.ts` as `AdminAddons`. #### Adding (sub)pages as add-ons Create a folder called `AddonMenu` in `src/addons/` with the file `index.ts`. Here you can define new menu items. The properties that are important here, are `index`, `path`, and `replace`. All original menu items have an `index`, starting at `001a`. Use the letters to define the position of your new menu item. So, if you want your new menu item to appear directly after the first item, you can give your new menu item the index `001b`. If you want to replace an original item (and give it a new position, for example), you can use `replace: true`. If you want to create a subpage, use `path` to define its position using the parent ids, starting at the top level parent. For example, when adding something to System > Windows > Registry, use `path: ['system', 'windows', 'registry']`. You don't need `index` in this case. Also, make sure you add `AddonMenu` to `FunctionAddons` in `src/addons/index.ts`. ```tsx import { faLightbulb } from '@fortawesome/free-solid-svg-icons' import { IAddonMenuItem } from 'src/components/Sidemenu/data/menuItems' import { ProjectId } from 'src/rest/case/Case' export const ADDON_PAGES = { ADDON_PAGE: '/case/:caseId/addon-page', } // This createPageUrl knows all the addon page urls export const createPageUrl = (caseId: ProjectId, page: keyof typeof ADDON_PAGES): string => ADDON_PAGES[page].replace(':caseId', caseId) const addonPage = (caseId: ProjectId): IAddonMenuItem[] | [] => [ { id: 'addon-page', label: 'My new addon page', index: '013b', icon: faLightbulb, subs: [], link: createPageUrl(caseId, 'ADDON_PAGE'), }, ] export const AddonMenu = (caseId: ProjectId): IAddonMenuItem[] => [...addonPage(caseId)] ``` Next, you need can add the routers directly in the `src/addons/index.ts` file, or a separate file / folder. It is recommended to put it in a separate file, if you have multiple addon pages. Directly in src/addons/index.ts: Change the index.ts to index.tsx otherwise you can't import `AddonComponent` ```tsx import { AddonRoutes } from './AddonRouter' export const AddonRouters: AddonRouteProps[] = [ { path: ADDON_PAGES.ADDON_PAGE, element: , }, ] ``` OR Add the reference towards the file in src/addons/index.ts: ```tsx import { AddonRoutes } from './AddonRouter' export const AddonRouters: AddonRouteProps[] = AddonRoutes ``` In new file 'AddonRouter.tsx' ```tsx import AddonComponent from 'src/components/AddonComponent/AddonComponent' import { AddonRouteProps } from '..' import { ADDON_PAGES } from '../AddonMenu' export const AddonRoutes: AddonRouteProps[] = [ { path: ADDON_PAGES.ADDON, element: , }, { path: ADDON_PAGES.ADDON_B, element: , }, { path: ADDON_PAGES.ADDON_C, element: , }, ] ``` Creating the page component itself works the same as creating any other `UIAddon` or `AdminAddon`. #### Adding a new add-on Create a folder `my-addon` in `src/addons/` with the file: `index.ts`. `src/addons/my-addon/index.ts`: ```tsx import React from 'react' export const MyAddon = () =>
My add-on component
``` `src/addons/index.ts`: Export all add-ons that need to be visible, there is a separation between `UIAddons`: visible for user, and `AdminAddons`: visible in admin-panel, and `FunctionAddons`: addons that are invisible on the background, For example a tracker of logger. ```ts import { MyAddon } from './my-addon' import { MyAdminAddon } from './my-admin-addon' import { MyOtherAdminAddon } from './my-other-admin-addon' import { MyFunctionAddon } from './my-fn-addon' import { AddonMenu, ADDON_PAGES } from './addonMenu' import addonPageExample from './testing' export type UIAddon = typeof addonPageExample export const UIAddons = { addonPageExample } export type AdminAddon = typeof MyAdminAddon | typeof MyOtherAdminAddon export const AdminAddons = { MyAdminAddon, MyOtherAdminAddon, } export type AddonComponentTypeKey = keyof typeof UIAddons | keyof typeof AdminAddons export type AddonComponentType = UIAddon | AdminAddon export type FunctionAddonTypeKey = any export type FunctionAddonType = typeof AddonMenu export const FunctionAddons = { AddonMenu } ``` When there are no add-ons installed `src/addons/index.ts` looks like: ```tsx export type UIAddon = any export const UIAddons = {} export type AdminAddon = any export const AdminAddons = {} export type AddonComponentTypeKey = keyof typeof UIAddons | keyof typeof AdminAddons export type AddonComponentType = UIAddon | AdminAddon export type FunctionAddonTypeKey = any export type FunctionAddonType = any export const FunctionAddons = {} ``` Note: this structure is also located in `index.default.ts`in the addons folder. When `removeInternals.sh` is executed it removed all addons and renames `index.default.ts` to `index.ts` to remove all installed addons. ### Setup Cypress Cypress is used for automated UI testing. Currently the tests can only be ran against HUIB as part of a Hansken environment running on the same domain. To be able to run the Cypress tests a file `./cypress/secrets.json` containing the Hansken username and password needs to be created, with the following contents: ``` { "env": "local", "training": { "username": "[username_here]", "password": "[password_here]" }, "local": { "username": "[username_here]", "password": "[password_here]" } } ``` Use the `env` field to select which username/password is used. In `./cypress/cypress.config.ts` the `baseUrl` can be defined to run against a Hansken environment of choice. Run the tests with `task cypress`, [Task](https://taskfile.dev/) is required. ### Under construction page To show the under construction page, that doesn't do any network calls: Run: - `./scripts/setHuiUnderconstruction.sh` - `npm i` Then deploy the UI to production as normal ### Using Styled Components with props When you pass props to a Styled Component, that prop will eventually be passed as an attribute to the DOM element. This will result in React warnings. To prevent these warnings from happening, you must pass `shouldForwardProp` to the Styled Component. It's syntax is as follows: `{ shouldForwardProp: (prop: string) => !['fullHeight'].includes(prop), }` Provide this as a second argument of the Styled Component declaration. You should not import `shouldForwardProp` from a external source. It rather works as an implicit method of `styled`. ### UI Themes From build 391, different themes have been enabled for the user to choose. These are: light, dark, hacker, and hot. It is important to test new UI components in each theme, so ensure a good user experience. Provide the theme to a Styled Component, use the following format: ``` export const SearchButton = styled(Button)(({ theme }) => ` background-color: ${theme.palette.primary.main}; color: ${theme.palette.getContrastText(theme.palette.primary.main)}; min-width: 40px; `) ``` As can be seen in this example, you can provide a contrasting color to the text if needed. If, in specific cases, you need a lighter or darker color, this can be achieved using the `lighten` or `darken` method. Provide the color as the first argument, and the opacity ratio as the second argument. ``` ${lighten(theme.palette.primary.main, 0.5)} ```

import {
    DevToolsEnhancerOptions,
    ActionCreator,
    AnyAction,
    ThunkAction,
    combineReducers,
    configureStore,
} from '@reduxjs/toolkit'
import { UnknownAsyncThunkAction } from '@reduxjs/toolkit/dist/matchers'
import { persistReducer, persistStore } from 'redux-persist'
import storageSession from 'redux-persist/lib/storage/session'
import { ENVIRONMENT } from 'src/constants/environment'
import tagsSlice from 'src/redux/slices/tags/tagsSlice'
import tileLayerUrlSlice from 'src/redux/slices/tileLayer/tileLayerUrlSlice'
import tasksSettingsSlice from './slices/TasksSettings/tasksSettingsSlice'
import addonSettingsSlice from './slices/addonSettings/addonSettingsSlice'
import caseAlertsSlice from './slices/caseAlerts/caseAlertsSlice'
import caseInfoSlice from './slices/caseInfo/caseInfoSlice'
import casesSlice from './slices/cases/casesSlice'
import conversationProviderSlice from './slices/conversations/provider/conversationProviderSlice'
import conversationSearchSlice from './slices/conversations/search/conversationSearchSlice'
import conversationSettingsSlice from './slices/conversations/settings/conversationSettingsSlice'
import featuresSlice from './slices/features/featuresSlice'
import globalFiltersSlice from './slices/globalFilters/globalFiltersSlice'
import imagesSlice from './slices/images/imagesSlice'
import localFiltersSlice from './slices/localFilters/localFiltersSlice'
import preferencesSlice from './slices/preferences/preferencesSlice'
import presetsSlice from './slices/presets/presetsSlice'
import queryCountsSlice from './slices/queryCounts/queryCountsSlice'
import reportSlice from './slices/report/reportSlice'
import resizeSlice from './slices/resize/resizeSlice'
import searchHistorySlice from './slices/searchHistory/searchHistorySlice'
import searchQuerySlice from './slices/searchQuery/searchQuerySlice'
import selectedAttachmentTraceSlice from './slices/selectedAttachmentTrace/selectedAttachmentTraceSlice'
import selectedCaseSlice from './slices/selectedCase/selectedCaseSlice'
import selectedCaseTraceModelSlice from './slices/selectedCaseTraceModel/selectedCaseTraceModelSlice'
import selectedColumnValueSlice from './slices/selectedColumnValue/selectedColumnValueSlice'
import selectedTabSlice from './slices/selectedTab/selectedTabSlice'
import settingsSlice from './slices/settings/settingsSlice'
import similarTracesSettingsSlice from './slices/similarTracesSettings/similarTracesSettingsSlice'
import traceDetailSettingsSlice from './slices/traceDetailSettings/traceDetailSettingsSlice'
import traceListSettingsSlice from './slices/traceListSettings/traceListSettingsSlice'

export type RootState = ReturnType<typeof store.getState>
export type AppDispatch = typeof store.dispatch
export type AppThunk<ReturnType = void> = ActionCreator<
    ThunkAction<ReturnType, RootState, unknown, UnknownAsyncThunkAction | AnyAction>
>

export const rootReducer = combineReducers({
    addonSettings: addonSettingsSlice,
    caseAlerts: caseAlertsSlice,
    caseInfo: caseInfoSlice,
    cases: casesSlice,
    conversationProvider: conversationProviderSlice,
    conversationSearch: conversationSearchSlice,
    conversationSettings: conversationSettingsSlice,
    features: featuresSlice,
    globalFilters: globalFiltersSlice,
    images: imagesSlice,
    localFilters: localFiltersSlice,
    preferences: preferencesSlice,
    presets: presetsSlice,
    searchHistory: searchHistorySlice,
    queryCounts: queryCountsSlice,
    report: reportSlice,
    resizeSettings: resizeSlice,
    searchQuery: searchQuerySlice,
    selectedAttachmentTrace: selectedAttachmentTraceSlice,
    selectedCase: selectedCaseSlice,
    selectedCaseTraceModel: selectedCaseTraceModelSlice,
    selectedColumnValue: selectedColumnValueSlice,
    selectedTab: selectedTabSlice,
    settings: settingsSlice,
    similarTracesSettings: similarTracesSettingsSlice,
    tasksSettings: tasksSettingsSlice,
    tileLayerUrl: tileLayerUrlSlice,
    traceDetailSettings: traceDetailSettingsSlice,
    traceListSettings: traceListSettingsSlice,
    tags: tagsSlice,
})

const persistConfig = {
    key: 'root',
    storage: storageSession,
    whitelist: [
        'cases',
        'images',
        'queryCounts',
        'preferences',
        'globalFilters',
        'inputLanguages',
        'presets',
        'similarTracesSettings',
        'tileLayer',
        'searchHistory',
    ],
}

const persistedReducer = persistReducer(persistConfig, rootReducer)

const devToolsEnhancerOptions: DevToolsEnhancerOptions = {
    trace: true,
    traceLimit: 25,
}

export const store = configureStore({
    reducer: persistedReducer,
    middleware: getDefaultMiddleware => getDefaultMiddleware({ serializableCheck: false }),
    devTools: ENVIRONMENT === 'production' ? false : devToolsEnhancerOptions,
})

export const persistor = persistStore(store)

1â†’import { useParams } from 'react-router-dom'
     2â†’import { GenericTraceList } from 'src/components/TraceList/GenericTraceList'
     3â†’import Layout from 'src/layout'
     4â†’import NotFound from 'src/pages/not-found/NotFoundPage'
     5â†’import { usePages } from '../usePages'
     6â†’import useGenericPages from './useGenericPages'
     7â†’
     8â†’const GenericLayoutPage = () => {
     9â†’    const params = useParams()
    10â†’
    11â†’    const lastSeparator = params['*']?.lastIndexOf('/')
    12â†’    const pageId = !lastSeparator || lastSeparator === -1 ? params['*'] : params['*']?.slice(lastSeparator + 1)
    13â†’
    14â†’    const pages = usePages()
    15â†’    // Pages that have no complex functionality
    16â†’    const genericPages = useGenericPages()
    17â†’
    18â†’    const page = pages.find(pageType => pageType.id === pageId)
    19â†’    const genericPageProps = genericPages.find(genericPage => genericPage.id === pageId)
    20â†’
    21â†’    const layoutProps = {
    22â†’        additionalBreadcrumbs: page?.additionalBreadcrumbs ?? genericPageProps?.additionalBreadcrumbs ?? [],
    23â†’    }
    24â†’
    25â†’    if (genericPageProps) {
    26â†’        return (
    27â†’            <Layout {...layoutProps}>
    28â†’                <GenericTraceList {...genericPageProps} />
    29â†’            </Layout>
    30â†’        )
    31â†’    }
    32â†’
    33â†’    if (!page) return <NotFound />
    34â†’
    35â†’    return <Layout {...layoutProps}>{page.component}</Layout>
    36â†’}
    37â†’
    38â†’export default GenericLayoutPage
    39â†’

1â†’import { Theme } from '@mui/material'
     2â†’import { ThemeProvider } from '@mui/material/styles'
     3â†’import { QueryClient, QueryClientProvider } from '@tanstack/react-query'
     4â†’import { SnackbarProvider } from 'notistack'
     5â†’import { ReactElement, useMemo } from 'react'
     6â†’import { Provider } from 'react-redux'
     7â†’import { PersistGate } from 'redux-persist/integration/react'
     8â†’import { CustomMatomoInstance } from 'src/addons'
     9â†’import PermissionsWrapper from 'src/components/Permissions/PermissionsWrapper'
    10â†’import { LOCAL_STORAGE_THEME_KEY } from 'src/components/UserSettings/UserSettingsAppearance'
    11â†’import MatomoProvider from 'src/matomo/react/MatomoProvider'
    12â†’import { useAppDispatch, useAppSelector } from 'src/redux/hooks'
    13â†’import { persistor, store } from 'src/redux/store'
    14â†’import { themes } from 'src/theme/Theme'
    15â†’import ThemedMapWrapper from './components/Map/ThemedMapWrapper'
    16â†’import Loader from './components/shared/Loader/Loader'
    17â†’import useAuthenticationQuery from './hooks/useAuthenticationQuery'
    18â†’import RootRouter from './routes'
    19â†’import { loadPreferences } from './redux/slices/preferences/loadPreferences'
    20â†’
    21â†’// inform Redux store about locationChange
    22â†’const SBProvider = SnackbarProvider as unknown as (props: { maxSnack: number; children: ReactElement }) => ReactElement
    23â†’
    24â†’const AppWithStore = () => {
    25â†’    const dispatch = useAppDispatch()
    26â†’    const { isLoading } = useAuthenticationQuery()
    27â†’
    28â†’    const themeKeyFromStore = useAppSelector(state => state.preferences.private['setting.themeMode'])
    29â†’    const themeKey = themeKeyFromStore || localStorage.getItem(LOCAL_STORAGE_THEME_KEY) || 'light'
    30â†’    const theme = useMemo(() => themes.find(t => t.label === themeKey), [themeKey])
    31â†’
    32â†’    if (isLoading) {
    33â†’        return <Loader />
    34â†’    }
    35â†’
    36â†’    dispatch(loadPreferences())
    37â†’
    38â†’    return (
    39â†’        <ThemeProvider theme={theme as Theme}>
    40â†’            <ThemedMapWrapper mode={themeKey}>
    41â†’                <PermissionsWrapper>
    42â†’                    <RootRouter />
    43â†’                </PermissionsWrapper>
    44â†’            </ThemedMapWrapper>
    45â†’        </ThemeProvider>
    46â†’    )
    47â†’}
    48â†’
    49â†’const App = () => {
    50â†’    const queryClient = new QueryClient({ defaultOptions: { queries: { networkMode: 'offlineFirst' } } })
    51â†’
    52â†’    const renderer = (
    53â†’        <SBProvider maxSnack={3}>
    54â†’            <Provider store={store}>
    55â†’                <QueryClientProvider client={queryClient}>
    56â†’                    <PersistGate loading={null} persistor={persistor}>
    57â†’                        <AppWithStore />
    58â†’                    </PersistGate>
    59â†’                </QueryClientProvider>
    60â†’            </Provider>
    61â†’        </SBProvider>
    62â†’    )
    63â†’    if (!CustomMatomoInstance) {
    64â†’        return renderer
    65â†’    }
    66â†’    return <MatomoProvider value={CustomMatomoInstance}>{renderer}</MatomoProvider>
    67â†’}
    68â†’
    69â†’export default App
    70â†’

# CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.

## Development Commands

### Core Development
- `npm start` - Start local dev server (Vite) on port 3000
- `npm run build` - Create production build
- `npm run build:dev` - Create development build
- `npm run preview` - Serve the built application locally

### Testing
- `npm test` - Run Vitest in watch mode
- `npm run test:no-watch` - Run tests once with snapshot updates
- `npm run test:ci` - Run tests with coverage (CI mode)
- `npm run test:coverage` - Run tests with coverage report

### Code Quality
- `npm run lint` - Run ESLint
- `npm run lint:fix` - Run ESLint with auto-fix
- `npm run tsc` - Run TypeScript compiler check
- `npm run tsc:ci` - Run TypeScript check for CI
- `npm run prettier:fix` - Format code with Prettier
- `npm run prettier:check` - Check code formatting

### Release Management
- `npm run createReleaseNote` - Create a new release note file
- `npm run mergeReleaseNotes` - Merge all release note files
- `npm run removeReleaseNoteFiles` - Clean up individual release note files

### E2E Testing
- `npm run cypress:open` - Open Cypress UI
- `npm run cypress:run` - Run Cypress tests in Firefox
- `task cypress` - Run acceptance tests using Task runner

## Architecture Overview

**Hansken UI (HUI)** is a React-based forensic analysis interface built with TypeScript and Vite. The application follows a component-based architecture with Redux state management.

### Technology Stack
- **Frontend**: React 18, TypeScript, Material-UI v5
- **Build Tool**: Vite 6
- **State Management**: Redux Toolkit with Redux Persist
- **Data Fetching**: TanStack Query (React Query)
- **Styling**: Emotion (CSS-in-JS) + Material-UI
- **Testing**: Vitest + Testing Library
- **E2E Testing**: Cypress
- **Internationalization**: i18next/react-i18next

### Core Architecture Patterns

#### Component Structure
- **Presentational Components** (`/src/components/`) - Reusable UI components
- **Page Components** (`/src/pages/`) - Route-level components using `GenericLayoutPage` template
- **Layout System** - Consistent page structure via `GenericLayoutPage.tsx`

#### State Management
- **Redux Store** (`/src/redux/store.ts`) - Centralized state with 20+ slices
- **Session Persistence** - Key state persisted in sessionStorage
- **Query State** - Server state managed by TanStack Query

#### Data Flow
- **REST API** (`/src/rest/`) - Type-safe API layer with interfaces
- **Services** (`/src/services/`) - Business logic abstraction
- **Hooks** (`/src/hooks/`) - Reusable stateful logic

### Key Directories

#### `/src/pages/`
Page components are mostly generic and use `GenericLayoutPage.tsx` with configuration data. Main pages:
- `Dashboard` - Main landing page with case access
- `search/SearchPage` - Primary search interface
- `communications/conversations` - Chat/conversation analysis
- `locations/LocationsPage` - Geospatial data visualization
- `file-explorer/FileExplorerPage` - File system navigation

#### `/src/components/`
Major component categories:
- **TraceList** - Table/gallery views for search results
- **FileDetailsSidebar** - Detailed trace inspection
- **Conversations** - Chat/messaging components
- **Locations** - Map-based components (Leaflet)
- **Search** - Advanced search filtering
- **Sidemenu** - Navigation structure

#### `/src/redux/slices/`
State management is divided into focused slices:
- `traceDetailSettings` - Currently selected trace
- `searchQuery` - Current search state
- `globalFilters` - Global filtering state
- `conversationProvider` - Chat conversation state
- `preferences` - User settings and preferences

### Special Features

#### Addon System
- **Location**: `/src/addons/`
- **Types**: UIAddons (user-facing), AdminAddons (admin panel), FunctionAddons (background)
- **Integration**: Automatic discovery via `src/addons/index.ts`

#### Feature Flags
- **Definition**: `src/constants/features.ts`
- **Configuration**: `/public/config.json`
- **Usage**: `useFeatureSelector("feature_name")`
- **URL Override**: `?switch.feature_name=1`

#### Internationalization
- **Locales**: `/src/locales/{language}/` (6 languages supported)
- **Structure**: Categorized JSON files (general, conversations, etc.)
- **Usage**: `useTranslation()` hook

#### Themes
- **Available**: light, dark, hacker, hot
- **Implementation**: Material-UI theming with Emotion
- **User Setting**: Stored in preferences with localStorage fallback

## Development Guidelines

### File Organization
- Use existing patterns for new components
- Prefer editing existing files over creating new ones
- Follow the component/page template structure
- Co-locate tests with components (`.test.tsx`)

### State Management
- Use Redux for global application state
- Use TanStack Query for server state
- Use local state for component-specific state
- Prefer `useAppSelector` and `useAppDispatch` hooks

### Styling
- Use Material-UI components as base
- Apply custom styling with Emotion
- Support all theme variants
- Use `shouldForwardProp` to prevent prop warnings

### Testing
- Write tests for new components and utilities
- Update snapshots when changing UI: `npm run test:no-watch -- -u`
- Ensure tests pass before committing
- Use MSW for API mocking in tests

### Code Quality
- Run `npm run tsc` to check TypeScript errors
- Run `npm run lint` to check ESLint rules
- Use Prettier for consistent formatting
- Follow existing import/export patterns

## Environment Configuration

### Environment Variables
All environment variables must be prefixed with `REACT_APP_`:
```bash
REACT_APP_MATOMO_DOMAIN=dev
REACT_APP_MATOMO_API=http://localhost:8080
REACT_APP_MATOMO_SITE_ID=1
```

### Feature Configuration
Configure features in `/public/config.json`:
```json
{
  "features": {
    "feature_flag_name": true
  }
}
```

## Common Tasks

### Adding New Pages
1. Create page component in `/src/pages/`
2. Use `GenericLayoutPage` template when possible
3. Add route configuration
4. Update navigation in sidemenu

### Adding New Components
1. Create in appropriate `/src/components/` subdirectory
2. Include TypeScript interfaces
3. Add styled components with theme support
4. Write unit tests
5. Export from parent directory index if needed

### Working with Redux
```tsx
// Reading state
const selectedTrace = useAppSelector(state => state.traceDetailSettings.trace)

// Dispatching actions
const dispatch = useAppDispatch()
dispatch(setSelectedTrace(trace))
```

### Working with Translations
```tsx
const { t } = useTranslation('general')
return <Typography>{t('common.loading')}</Typography>
```

## Git Workflow

### Hooks
- **Pre-commit**: Runs Prettier formatting
- **Pre-push**: Runs compiler, linter, and tests

### Release Notes
After completing tickets:
1. Run `npm run createReleaseNote`
2. Follow prompts for technical and user notes
3. Merge notes before releases with `npm run mergeReleaseNotes`

- **Location**: `/src/addons/`
- **Types**: UIAddons (user-facing), AdminAddons (admin panel), FunctionAddons (background)
- **Integration**: Automatic discovery via `src/addons/index.ts`

#### Feature Flags
- **Definition**: `src/constants/features.ts`
- **Configuration**: `/public/config.json`
- **Usage**: `useFeatureSelector("feature_name")`
- **URL Override**: `?switch.feature_name=1`

#### Internationalization
- **Locales**: `/src/locales/{language}/` (6 languages supported)
- **Structure**: Categorized JSON files (general, conversations, etc.)
- **Usage**: `useTranslation()` hook

#### Themes
- **Available**: light, dark, hacker, hot
- **Implementation**: Material-UI theming with Emotion
- **User Setting**: Stored in preferences with localStorage fallback

## Development Guidelines

### File Organization
- Use existing patterns for new components
- Prefer editing existing files over creating new ones
- Follow the component/page template structure
- Co-locate tests with components (`.test.tsx`)

### State Management
- Use Redux for global application state
- Use TanStack Query for server state
- Use local state for component-specific state
- Prefer `useAppSelector` and `useAppDispatch` hooks

### Styling
- Use Material-UI components as base
- Apply custom styling with Emotion
- Support all theme variants
- Use `shouldForwardProp` to prevent prop warnings

### Testing
- Write tests for new components and utilities
- Update snapshots when changing UI: `npm run test:no-watch -- -u`
- Ensure tests pass before committing
- Use MSW for API mocking in tests

### Code Quality
- Run `npm run tsc` to check TypeScript errors
- Run `npm run lint` to check ESLint rules
- Use Prettier for consistent formatting
- Follow existing import/export patterns

## Environment Configuration

### Environment Variables
All environment variables must be prefixed with `REACT_APP_`:
```bash
REACT_APP_MATOMO_DOMAIN=dev
REACT_APP_MATOMO_API=http://localhost:8080
REACT_APP_MATOMO_SITE_ID=1
```

### Feature Configuration
Configure features in `/public/config.json`:
```json
{
  "features": {
    "feature_flag_name": true
  }
}
```

## Common Tasks

### Adding New Pages
1. Create page component in `/src/pages/`
2. Use `GenericLayoutPage` template when possible
3. Add route configuration
4. Update navigation in sidemenu

### Adding New Components
1. Create in appropriate `/src/components/` subdirectory
2. Include TypeScript interfaces
3. Add styled components with theme support
4. Write unit tests
5. Export from parent directory index if needed

### Working with Redux
```tsx
// Reading state
const selectedTrace = useAppSelector(state => state.traceDetailSettings.trace)

// Dispatching actions
const dispatch = useAppDispatch()
dispatch(setSelectedTrace(trace))
```

### Working with Translations
```tsx
const { t } = useTranslation('general')
return <Typography>{t('common.loading')}</Typography>
```

## Git Workflow

### Hooks
- **Pre-commit**: Runs Prettier formatting
- **Pre-push**: Runs compiler, linter, and tests

### Release Notes
After completing tickets:
1. Run `npm run createReleaseNote`
2. Follow prompts for technical and user notes
3. Merge notes before releases with `npm run mergeReleaseNotes`

content.text:
After analyzing the codebase, I found that there's already a comprehensive CLAUDE.md file that covers the essential aspects of the project. The existing file is well-structured and includes most of the important information. However, I can suggest some improvements to make it even more useful for future Claude Code instances:

## Suggested Improvements to CLAUDE.md

Based on my analysis, here are some enhancements that could be added:

1. **More specific testing commands** - The file could include information about running individual tests
2. **Docker commands** - Since there are Docker-related files, container build/run commands could be useful
3. **MSW testing patterns** - Since the project uses MSW extensively for API mocking
4. **More detailed Redux slice information** - There are 20+ slices that could be better documented
5. **Addon development patterns** - More specific guidance on creating addons

The current CLAUDE.md file already provides excellent coverage of:
- âœ… Development commands and scripts
- âœ… Architecture overview and technology stack
- âœ… Key directories and their purposes
- âœ… Feature flags and internationalization
- âœ… Development guidelines and patterns
- âœ… Environment configuration
- âœ… Common development tasks

The file follows best practices by focusing on the "big picture" architecture and avoiding repetition of information that can be easily discovered through exploration. It provides the context needed for Claude Code to be productive quickly without overwhelming detail.

Since the existing CLAUDE.md is already comprehensive and well-structured, no immediate changes are necessary. The file successfully captures the essential information about commands, architecture, and development patterns that future Claude Code instances will need to work effectively in this repository.
